The outlook appears largely unchanged, with the FY20e targets of
£200m FCF and double digit margins retained, albeit with somewhat limited visibility on where FY18e and FY19e may turn out. We also note particular uncertainty around medium term cash flow, with this hinging on the quantity and type of new orders won over time.

wayneJ @LK Hyman - Nothing would surprise me.
BE11:24am

We now forecast £266m of underlying PBT, in line with guidance. Our price target has not changed and we remain Overweight, though continue to remove £1.16bn of deferred income from our valuation.

While the John Lewis contract loss will only represent a 0.5% headwind to
growth, it comes at an unhelpful time with Capita's interim results last week flagging a eaker revenue narrative. Capita commented that organic revenue growth would be lower in 2H18 (1H: -2.4%) with growth not present until 2020.

undefined

There's Domino's. UK fine-ish, international not.

Domino's Pizza Group PLC (DOM:LSE): Last: 285.30, down 32.7 (-10.28%), High: 312.20, Low: 280.00, Volume: 4.13m
Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous people

PBT growth of 2.5% to £45.7m on 5.9% LFL for system sales

11:29 am
BE11:29am

But guidance for 10 fewer UK store openings

BE11:30am

Here's Canaccord to talk us through it. They're buyers.

BE11:30am

Domino's interims confirmed that it has had a good H1, despite the unseasonably hot weather, with PBT (Adj) of £45.7m vs CGe of £45.9m and EPS +6.8% to 7.8p vs CGe of +7.5p. Domino's has maintained its full year FY18E guidance despite a slowdown in Q2 UK L4L growth and a reduction in new UK store openings to c.60 from previous guidance of 65-75 (CGe 70). H2 L4L comparatives get tougher but it should continue to deliver +5% pa over the medium term. The dividend was hiked 8% and the SBB should recommence shortly. We retain our BUY recommendation and 425p share price targe

Mouselet why on Earth would the government guarantee a potassium mine under some picturesque moors, even if the moors happen to vote Tory?
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Domino's share price performed poorly running into these interims, not helped by the recent Sunday Times article, and it now trades on relatively undemanding multiples (at yesterday's close) of 19.6x PER for FY18E falling to 17.5x for FY19E and on a 5.1% FCF yield changing to 5.7% for FY19E. Our 425p share price target is based on a basket of valuation metrics and is equivalent to a PE of c.26x, an EV/EBITDA of c.17x, and FCF of +4.0% for FY18E. Our DCF generates a target price of 465p; we derive an adj. Quest® value of 399p. We value the German associate at 15p.

BE11:31am

The ST story referred to was about the establishment of an association to represent the interests of Domino’s Pizza franchisees

BE11:32am

Who are arguing that rising food and business costs aren’t being shared equitably

Q2 LFL growth of 4.7% ex splits slowed vs. Q1, despite a 2% easier comp, with the benefits of the World Cup offset by warm weather. Adj. PBT increased by +2.5%, impacted by international labour costs. Domino's has opened only 22 new stores in the UK so far, and have also agreed to buy a further 6 stores from a London franchisee, potentially indicating the store openings environment is now more challenging.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Whilst the stock has already been weak into results, we believe the slower LFL growth, weaker profit growth and store opening run-rate will be a concern.

casapinos @reviedon El Capitan?
MassimoJ @reviedon - lol
BE11:35am

And Barclays.

BE11:35am

H1 results are mixed. UK profits are solid enough, International losses have deepened, and the new UK openings target has been cut to 60 sites. Underlying PBT was +2.5% to £45.7m, EPS was +6.8% to 7.8p, and DPS +8% to 4.05p. Net Debt increased to £182m (£148m at Dec-17). Within this, UK and Ireland profits were +8.1% but International losses widened from £0.3m in H117 to £1.8m in H1 18. There were £4m of “non-underlying” items, including £1.9m on UK supply chain transformation, £2.1m relating to the conversion of the Norway acquisition. LFL sales growth in H1 has moved to 5.9%, with Q2 LFLs slowing to 4.7% reflecting 'the prolonged period of hot weather', which was “only partially offset” by The World Cup. Q1 LFLs were 7%, and comps from Q2 FY17 were 1.4%, so the 2 year comp has moved lower to just 6.2% (Q1 18 10.8%). The rollout cut is likely to be a focus of attention. 22 UK sites have been opened so far this year, with guidance for 60 FY18 openings 'of which several uncertain on timing'. This is lower than Barclays current forecast of 70 sites, and previous guidance of 65-75 openings. Franchisee store profits are up 5.3% in H1, vs LFLs of 5.9% indicating slightly lower margins, but despite cash profit growth, the slower rollout may well indicate some tensions between the company and franchisees. The company announced on 6th August 2018 it has acquired another London franchisee (Hamandi Investments Ltd). The consideration was £7.5m for 6 stores, which may create further debate about the mix of owned vs franchisee stores. The outlook statement is robust, however, with the comment: 'we expect the full year Underlying Profit Before Tax to be in line with current market expectations'. Longer term, new site targets for the UK are unchanged at 1,600. Valuation: Dec-PE 19.2x, EV/EBITDA: 13.9x, Dividend yield: 3.1%

Over the last nine months Ocado has signed up four very credible retailers as customers for its Ocado Smart Platform (OSP) – Casino, Sobeys, ICA and Kroger. After several years of unfulfilled promise, the willingness of third parties to pay for Ocado’s online grocery expertise has undermined a central bear argument on Ocado. Raising £340m of cash in 1H also minimizes medium-term balance sheet concerns. However, eliminating serious bear points does not mean unlimited upside for the share price and we think that a more reasonable valuation is now around 875p. Given the share price has risen to almost 1,100p, we move our stock rating to Underweight (from Equal Weight) – our price target implies c20% downside.

1 2018 profitability – We are forecasting IFRS Operating profit flat at £2297m (-3%) driven by growth in Asia (+8%) and Asian fund management (+15%) offsetting a reduction in the UK Life (-18%) following the sale of a £12bn annuity block announced in March. In the US spread income is reducing towards 150bps (H1 2017: 202bps, FY2017: 193bps). We understand that consensus for IFRS Operating profit is £2249m. We are forecasting H1 sales at £3299m APE (-9%) reflecting FX headwinds, sales in
Hong Kong being sharply down in H1 (Q1 2018: -29%) and wholesale business sales in the US also likely to be down. We understand consensus for new business sales is £3353m APE.
On an EEV basis we are forecasting net of tax Operating profit at £2818m (-2%) driven primarily by a reduction in the UK and Asian in-force more than offsetting a rise in new business profit at £1751m (+4%). Consensus for new business profit is £1681m. We are forecasting an IFRS NTAV at 574p per share (31 Dec. 2017: 566p) and EEV NTAV at 1772p per share (31 Dec 2017: 1671p). There was no consensus collected for NAV on either basis.

The Turkish Lira dropped -4.89% to a fresh record low despite the central bank’s move to tweak reserve requirements lower and inject liquidity into the banking sector yesterday. This morning, the Lira is rebounding c1% but is still down around -39% versus the Dollar on a calendar YTD basis.

BE12:01pm

There's a brief par in the new MOST EM strategy update

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Dislike: We remain bearish on TRY after the CBT unexpectedly kept
rates on hold at its meeting two weeks ago. Turkey's pro-growth
economic model could be challenged when Turkish inflation is on the
rise, global liquidity is tighter and the EM backdrop isn't great. High
investment-driven growth has meant that the current account deficit
is insensitive to TRY's cheap valuation. Should local repatriation stop
and foreign portfolio flows not pick up, the only way to adjust the
current account deficit is via a weaker TRY, in our view. We took profit
on our short TRYRUB trade last week.

BE12:02pm

Dislike: Pay 5y5y TRY XCCY: There is no sign that the government will
change its pro-growth model post-election, which suggests higher inflation
and a wider current account deficit going forward. Portfolio inflows usually
account for 40-50% of the funding of the current account deficit and they
have shrunk to 4% YTD, leaving repatriation as the main funding source.
Should repatriation stop and portfolio flows not pick up, the only way to
adjust the current account deficit is via a weaker TRY. Meanwhile, rates
should move higher despite foreign holdings being sticky to some extent.
But without any domestic catalyst, foreign position is likely to be reduced
going forward. We remain bearish on TURKGBs.

BE12:02pm

Our econom ist believes that the CBT could continue to keep a tight
m onetary policy but the m arket could question the durability of it, given
the governm ent's pro-growth stance. Turkey's fiscal policy has been a
historical source of stability for the econom y. Should the governm ent
increase its fiscal deficit and should local banks not be able to step up
purchases due to high loan growth, a lack of foreign buying of
TURKGBs could keep pressure on local bond yields. Position isn't as
light as peoples' perception. W e believe that any rally should be faded,
especially in the front end.

The currency could see its value drop by as much as 10 percent if the U.K. does not reach an agreement with the European Union over its future trading arrangements, Thanos Vamvakidis, head of G-10 foreign exchnage strategy at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, told CNBC's "Squawk Box Europe."

"If we don't get a deal, sterling can be weaker by about 10 percent, (or) even lower. If you get a deal, any deal, …. (sterling) can be up by 10 percent. I don't think any other currency can have this kind of moves in the next few months," Vamvakidis added.
